Kinder parents (Tuesday and Wednesday),

We want to make this tough situation as best we can for you...

While we cannot have parents walk their child inside this year, here's what we can do:

Our staff will not park in the upper lot on Tuesday Morning. Instead, we want you to feel free to park there from 8 to 8:15 after buses have already gone from the area. You can take as much of that 15 minutes as you need to get your little one excited, comfortable, and ready as possible to take on their first day of school before walking them to the aide at the gate.

The instructional aide will walk them to the door where their teacher will welcome them and give you a big wave. We hope this helps this transition in life for your child...and you :)

The District welcomed the staff back in a unique and fun team-building way for their first day back of the 2020-21 school year with a surprise --the staff got to participate in ASD's First Annual--"The Amazing Race - Pagosa style".

The teams raced to complete a series of 12 tasks from clues that took them all over town racing to do such things as: take a picture with the county commissioner, find the Safety Resource Officers in your school and take a selfie with them, document Family School Bee House messages, sing the Pagosa Pirates fight song on stage...and so much more. Teams raced to the finish line at the stadium where they joined their peers for some water and a snack.

What a fun way to start the year off together as staff. We love our staff and we cant wait to see our students again soon. Go Pirates!!! 2020-21 is going to be a year to remember!!!

April is National Autism Awareness Month. In 1970, the Autism Society launched am ongoing nationwide effort to promote autism awareness and assure that all affected by autism are able to achieve the highest quality of life possible. In 1972, the Autism Society launched the first annual National Autistic Children's week, which evolved into National Autism Awareness Month (NAAM). This April, we continue our efforts to spread awareness, promote acceptance, and ignite change.

The Autism Awareness Ribbon - The puzzle pattern reflects the complexity of the autism spectrum. The different colors and shapes represent the diversity of the people and families living with this condition. The brightness of the ribbon signals hope - hope that through increased awareness of autism, and through early intervention and access to appropriate service/supports, people with autism will lead full lives able to interact with the world on their own terms

"Do you realize the funnest part of school-- the kids--- are what's been taken from us? A little sad tonight." -PSES Teacher

There is a huge hole in my teachers' hearts that only kids fill. They are the reason we smile, cry, try harder, do our best, and desire to reach every one of them. Teachers' hearts fill up and our eyes light up when we recognize our kids are learning. That's hard to do remotely. As a principal, I'm trying hard to help them be equipped for this... equipping them for the emotional impact is the toughest part even as we're all worried and praying for our parents.

We're missing you PSES students. Be kind to your parents; they are doing double duty!
